item.title: Add multiple Networks via form
item.description:
1. Create a new VM via the web form
  2. Add both a management network and an external VLAN network
  3. Validate both interfaces exist in the VM
    • ip link list
  4. Ping the VM from another VM that is only on the management VLAN
  5. Ping the VM from an external machine

Expected Results

  1. The VM should create
  2. You should see three interfaces listed in VM
  3. You should get responses from pinging the VM
  4. You should get responses from pinging the VM

item.description:

Category:

Environment Setup

Verification Steps

  1. Enable virtual network with harvester-mgmt in harvester
  2. Create VLAN 806 with id 806 and set to default auto mode

item.title: Add VLAN network (e2e_be)
item.description:
Environment setup

This should be done on a Harvester setup with at least 2 NICs and at least 2 nodes. This is easily tested in Vagrant

Verification Steps

  1. Open settings on a harvester cluster
  2. Navigate to the VLAN settings page
  3. Click Enabled
  4. Check dropdown for NICs and verify that percentage is showing 100%
  5. Add the NIC
  6. Click Save
  7. Validate that it has updated in settings

Expected Results

  1. You should be able to add the VLAN network device
  2. You should see in the settings list that it has your new default NIC

item.title: Delete external VLAN network via form
item.description:
1. On a VM with both an external VLAN and a management VLAN delete the external VLAN via the web form
  2. Validate interface was removed with
    • ip link list
  3. Ping the VM from another VM that is only on the management VLAN
  4. Ping the VM from an external machine

Expected Results

  1. The VM should update and reboot
  2. You should only see one interface (and the loopback) in the list
  3. You should not be able to ping the VM on the external VLAN
  4. You should get responses from the VM

item.title: Disable and enable vlan cluster network
item.description:
• Related issues: #1529 Failed to enable vlan cluster network after disable and enable again, display “Network Error”

Category:

  • Network

Verification Steps

  1. Open settings and config vlan network
  2. Enable network and set default harvester-mgmt
  3. Disable network
  4. Enable network again
  5. Check Host, Network and harvester dashboard
  6. Repeat above steps several times

Expected Results

  1. User can disable and enable network with default harvester-mgmt.
  2. Harvester dashboard and network work as expected

item.title: Enabling vlan on a bonded NIC on vagrant install
item.description:
• Related issues: #1541 Enabling vlan on a bonded NIC breaks the Harvester setup

Category:

  • Network

Verification Steps

  1. Pull ipxe example from https://github.com/harvester/ipxe-examples
  2. Vagrant pxe install 3 nodes harvester
  3. Access harvester settings page
  4. Open settings -> vlan
  5. Enable virtual network and set with bond0
  6. Navigate to every page to check harvester is working
  7. Create a vlan based on bon0

Expected Results

Enable virtual network with bond0 will not make harvester service out of work.

item.title: Switch the vlan interface of harvester node
item.description:
• Related issues: #1464 VM pods turn to the terminating state after switching the VLAN interface

Category:

  • Network

Verification Steps

  1. User ipxe-example to build up 3 nodes harvester
  2. Login harvester dashboard -> Access Settings
  3. Enable vlan network with harvester-mgmt NIC interface
  4. Create a VM using harvester-mgmt
  5. Disable vlan network
  6. Enable vlan network and select bond0 interface
  7. Check host and vm is working
  8. Directly switch network interface from bond0 to harvester-mgmt without disable it.
  9. Check host and vm is working

Expected Results

  1. Switch the VLAN interface of this host can’t affect Host and VM operation.
  2. All harvester node keep in running status

item.title: VIP configured in a VLAN network should be reached
item.description:
• Related issue: #1424 VIP configured in a VLAN network can not be reached

Category:

  • Network

Environment Setup

  • The network environment must have vlan network configured and also have DHCP server prepared on your testing vlan

Verification Steps

  1. Enable virtual network with harvester-mgmt
  2. Open Network -> Create a virtual network
  3. Provide network name and correct vlan id
  4. Open Route, use the default auto setting
  5. Create a VM and use the created route
  6. SSH to harvester node
  7. Ping the IP of the created VM
  8. Create a virutal network
  9. Provide network name and correct vlan id
  10. Open Route, use the manual setting
  11. Provide the CIDR and Gateway value
  12. Repeat step 5 - 7

Expected Results

  1. Check the auto route vlan can be detected with running status
  2. Check the manual route vlan can be detected with running status
  3. Check the VM can get IP based on auto or manual vlan route
  4. Check can ping VM IP from harvester node

item.title: VIP is accessibility with VLAN enabled on management port
item.description:
Ref: https://github.com/harvester/harvester/issues/1722

Verify Items

  • VIP should be accessible when VLAN enabled on management port

Case: Single Node enables VLAN on management port

  1. Install Harvester with single node
  2. Login to dashboard then navigate to Settings
  3. Edit vlan to enable VLAN on harvester-mgmt
  4. reboot the node
  5. after reboot, login to console
  6. Run the command should not contain any output
    • sudo -s
    • kubectl get pods -A --template '{{range .items}}{{.metadata.name}}{{"\n"}}{{end}}' | grep harvester-network-controller-manager | xargs kubectl logs -n harvester-system | grep "Failed to update lock"
  7. Repeat step 4-6 with 10 times, should not have any error
